remixed_from.author: Exterminate
remixed_from.title: CR-10 Steampunk Legs - Control Box under bed mod

description.text:
This is a remix of thing 2332197 by Exterminate. Based upon my personal preferences, I made the following alterations:

  1. Total leg length is reduced to only 135mm instead of 152.5mm. This allows the CR-10 control box to still slide back under the printer but keeps the cables 17.5mm closer to the printer.
  2. I put a radius on all sides of the mounting plates. This makes the legs look much better once they are mounted.
  3. I took the BALL/MOUNT out from under the claw feet. I like the looks of the feet sitting directly on my work table instead of the feet sitting atop the Ball/Mount (just a personal preference).
  4. The mounting plates were not completely flat originally, so I totally flattened them out nice and straight.
  5. I also assured that each leg is precisely the same height and that the bottoms of the feet are all in the same flat parallel plane to the mounting plates.
  6. This single stl file contains all 4 legs, so there's no need to copy the legs.
  7. I used 5 layers on top, bottom and sides to make them really strong. I've also included the CURA 3.1.0 gcode slicer file for the legs. This is the exact gcode file that I printed the legs from that are shown in the included pictures herein.
  8. I've also included a pdf file that shows the CURA specific settings that I used to print these (in case you want to see such details OR in case you don't use CURA).

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used Nery's recommendation to get around not using supports by using 5 perimeters and 20% zigzag infill. I set the temp to 205c on my Solutech PLA and got great layer adhesion.

comments.text: This looks like a good mod, I am curious, if using the bed heated, will having the control box under the heated bed end up causing problems with the control box?
comments.author: johnmcwGeo

comments.text: I can't imagine that the heat from the heated bed could cause any problems. When using these legs and placing your controller underneath the CR 10, there is still a very significant air gap between the controller box and the heated bed plate.
comments.author: johnmcwGeo

comments.text: Where exactly do you set these settings in Cura 3? I know where the infill pattern is hidden but what are the 5 perimeters?
comments.author: fr33s7yl0r

comments.text: There's a pdf file that is included on this object. If you download and open that file, you can see my CURA settings. I am using CURA 3.1.0  Beneath the section named "Shell" there is a setting named "Wall Line Count". That is the same as perimeters. When I use a layer height of .2 and set my "Wall Thickness" value to 2, the "Wall Line Count" value automatically calculates and sets to 5. I'm unsure what what angles this setting work up to, but I also set my top and bottom thickness to 2mm. This results in the entire model having 2mm thick solid walls.
comments.author: fr33s7yl0r

comments.text: Thank you! I did exactly the same yesterday. Kind of figured it out by reading all setting descriptions. It printed perfectly. Now is time to put the printer on its new legs :)))

title: Cable Chain Ends for Felix 3D Printer

description.text:
End pieces for a Felix Printer upper cable chain. The ends were matched with a 10 x 15 mm R18 drag chain that was purchased on amazon for $14 Canadian. This was inspired by a project that a friend suggested I check out which can be found here. I hope to have a cable chain design completed for the print bed wires sometime soon.

Using this chain will require routing all wires from the print head toward the rear of the printer. I discovered that the parts of the Felix print head facilitated this quite nicely.

The frame-side cable chain end does not require any support material but I used a brim for good bed adhesion. It snaps in to the extruded frame of the felix printer. The print head end requires internal support material, but no brim. It attaches to the lower frame of the print head using the belt tensioner M4 bolt and another M4 bolt in the side of the print head lower frame that will require drilling a hole. See the pictures for details.

Soon after getting my Kossel Clear from Blue Eagle Labs, it became very obvious that a fan was a necessity. So I built this. It should be noted that I mounted the hotend on top the platform, instead of under it as the directions (video) indicated. This means the hotend does not hang down as far. The first fan I tried was about an inch thick, heave for it's size, and drew 0.55 amp! The RAMPS/Arduino could not handle it at full power for more then a couple of minutes, then the power would blink out and the printer would reboot... failed print. It did work well at 80%, moved a LOT of air, but the center of gravity was so high that it caused the hotend to wobble all over during infill. So a smaller fan was needed. I had some of the one in the picture, draws only 0.09 amp, but does not move nearly as much air. :(
In fact it is not enough. So I decided to add two fans, one on each side, and maybe a third in the original top location. I have not yet printed the 3 port version, but do not see any problem printing it. Note that it has built in support, which should break right out. I could not get my slicer to make sensible support, so I just built it in.

You will notice that I did not remove the cone wall in the side fan ports, this was intentional.  If you only want to run a top fan, but want the option of possibly using to side fans ...  
Also, I had the idea to hand cut slots, then heat the plastic and bend it inward to make downward facing louvers.  Printing louvers would be quite a hassle, but it might be quite easy to put them in afterward by hand.  That was the thought.  
The wall is so thin that it cuts very easy.

description.text:
This is a hanging ornament remix of Glitch's Millenium Falcon. It's perfect for the rear-view mirror, Christmas tree, etc.

The print in the cover photo was done on a Prusa i3 MK2 MMU as follows:

  • mf_top_combined.stl silver PLA - may require supports
  • mf_bottom.stl silver PLA

For those of you who dislike printing with supports (and are hopefully better at gluing pieces together than I am), I have also included separate top and middle pieces similar to Glitch's original model.

I recommend scaling the models up to 150% for printing, as the default size is quite small. At 150%, the ornament measures approximately 63mm x 45mm.

After printing the parts, add string/wire hanger to the top portion and glue it all together.

Happy printing!

description.text: Here is my Grail-o-matic: a customizable design you can use to make vases, cups, chalices, or even Tuscan pillars by rotating a profile you draw about an axis, as if on a lathe. Part of the fun is designing your own Rubin vase illusion. See the faces in the negative space around the default design? You can make faceted columns as well as smoother cylinders by reducing the number of rotation segments. The output is a solid model intended to be printed with no infill and no top layers. (Update: if you include the interior concavity in your cross section drawing, you can print with regular infill etc settings. Here's an example!) Printing Tips Here is a quick screencast showing how to use the polygon sketch control in Customizer to draw a profile for your chalice. Observe how I drag the cursor outside the box to ensure the drawing is flush with the top, bottom, and left edge (which is treated as the lathe axis by default). http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1kMebhH0xIM It is quite possible to make designs that are difficult to print without supports or infill, if at all. Pay careful attention to the slope of the lines you draw - steep horizontal overhangs will be trouble. For example, see the attached close-up. The overhangs in the design are translucent in my test print, and unfortunately somewhat porous (the rest of the print holds water).
Part of my Customizable Containers series.

I printed the pictured test copy of the default design in brown PLA on my Printrbot Simple at 0.8 scale. 0.1 layer height; 4 perimeters; 0 infill; 0 top layers; 13 bottom layers.  
As noted in the Printing Tips section of the description, it's watertight except for the steepest parts of the design, which came out a bit porous.

An arm to mount a Raspberry Pi Zero Camera to a Felix 3D printer. It was designed to use this Pi Zero Camera Case, but could be easily modified for your custom needs.

Instructions:

  1. Print the two test pieces (small ring and cylinder), the two mount pieces (GoPro style hinge), and the Pi case holder. The three prong mount and the Pi case holder will require support material when printing.

  2. The ring (test piece 1) should easily fit around the cylinder (test piece 2) without any slop. Likewise, the two GoPo style mount pieces should fit together with an M4 bolt and nut and should allow for easy rotation when the bolt is loose, and lock in place when the bolt is tightened down. The cylindrical rotator piece has a protrusion that should fit in the recess in the base of the three prong GoPro style mount. The base of the two prong GoPro style mount should fit in to the recess in the base of the Pi case holder. Incorporate any necessary test piece design changes in to the full size parts and print them out. A little post processing should take care of fitment issues in the GoPro style mounts and Pi case holder.

  3. Scuff any mating surfaces with sand paper and Glue the rotator to the three prong mount, and the two prong mount to the Pi case holder. I use a slow cure two part epoxy for gluing 3D printed parts.

  4. I designed two arms, one with small openings for use with custom USB OTG cables or those with long runs of wire on the micro USB side (Paspberry Pi side), and another arm with larger openings for use with most common USB OTG cables. Run wires through the arm, then clip the arm to the frame of your printer. The clips that secure the arm to the printer frame may brake if you try to remove the arm, so decide where you want the arm to be mounted before clipping it to the frame

  5. Insert your Raspberry Pi and plug in the wires. Adjust the camera rotation and tilt to get the best view of your printer, and your done!

Here is the 1/15th scale 25-C Tender to go with the 4-8-8-4 "Big Boy" Locomotive I did for Makerbot in 2014 !!

Makerbot Clear................>0.1lb (.05kg)

The parts are compressed in the Tender STL parts.RAR file to make it easier to download.

print_settings.Notes:: Print with brim and supports. Any resolution is fine for the handle, but the smoother  you can print the base and top the better - I recommend taking it nice and slow and at 0.1mm, since it's not the easiest print in the world.

description.text:
A slim safety razor designed for comfort and optimized to be 3D printed at a low filament cost. It has 3 parts - the top, the base and the handle.

It takes standard double edged razor blades, and an M3 nut/screw combo (which probably makes its handle interchangeable with others, such as the original jpearce design or Big-E's).

You'll need at least an M3x16 screw, though I think an M3x20 will fit in there fine.

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The parts are all designed to be printed vertically, as they are oriented in the .STLs. I have no promises on how good it will feel if you print it any other way.

Print with brim and supports. Any resolution is fine for the handle, but the smoother you can print the base and top the better - I recommend taking it nice and slow and at 0.1mm, since it's not the easiest print in the world.

Sand off the brim or it'll get scratchy; the supports just have to be popped off. I put a small hole on the back of the M3 nut cavity so the supports inside the handle are easier to push out.

Assembly:

  1. Sandwich razor blade between top and base, taking care to line up the blade and the holes cleanly
  2. Insert M3 nut into larger hole on side of handle
  3. Screw everything together

Thanks, jpearce.

28Chibi is a new generation of minis made to be printed flat on the bed. Inspired by the likes of DutchMogul's DungeonDoll's and GrumpyRobot's FlatMinis, These print quickly and reliably on high- or low-end printers alike.

Unlike normal 28Chibi models, this one is best printed vertically at whichever layer height you like. I'd also encourage thick infill (or a thick skin) - printing at 0.4mm skin and 20% infill left these breaking early on. I now print them at 100% and in a few different colours for easy tracking.

I'm much too late for Halloween, but the traditional skeleton is here! This one was quite fun to make, and works as a new base for armour, add-ons and the like. This is 28mm sized and a medium creature.

28Chibi is a new generation of minis made to be printed flat on the bed. Inspired by the likes of DutchMogul's DungeonDoll's and GrumpyRobot's FlatMinis, These:

  • Print quickly and reliably on high- or low-end printers alike.
  • Are sized for 28mm games such as D&D, Pathfinder, Shadowrun, Starwars EofE etc
  • Storage is space efficient and safe due to the flat-pack & peg-and-hole base design (The peg is 2x2mm, so if the included base is not to your liking adding a slightly larger hole to your preferred base is a quick modification.)
  • The hands are designed for modular equipment, and should generally also accept objects designed in the FlatMini style.

The detail steps up in increments of 0.6mm, allowing for a variety of different layer heights to still print these crisply. 0.2mm is my go to, but higher or lower values (such as 0.1, 0.12 or 0.3) all work great too.

So I've gone back to the print, made some minor spacing corrections, updated it to reliable 0.6mm spacing, and made it the modern pegged type.

28Chibi is a new generation of minis made to be printed flat on the bed. Inspired by the likes of DutchMogul's DungeonDoll's and GrumpyRobot's FlatMinis.

These new minis:

  • Print quickly and reliably on high- or low-end printers alike.
  • Are sized for 28mm games such as D&D, Pathfinder, Shadowrun, Starwars EofE etc
  • Storage is space efficient and safe due to the flat-pack & peg-and-hole base design (The peg is 2x2mm, so if the included base is not to your liking adding a slightly larger hole to your preferred base is a quick modification.)
  • The hands are designed for modular equipment, and should generally also accept objects designed in the FlatMini style.

The detail steps up in increments of 0.6mm, allowing for a variety of different layer heights to still print these crisply. 0.2mm is my go to, but higher or lower values (such as 0.1, 0.12 or 0.3) all work great too.

This is a remix of another fan duct made for the Sunhokey Prusa I3.

This has had the bolt flange modified for the smaller bearings on the x axis on the 2015 version of the printer. I have added lots of room up or down to the flange to allow for shortter or taller extruders .

My bearing housings we not threaded all the way through I simply used self taping metal screws to attach it to the bearing holder.

This is an Annis Hag (Large) sized for a 28mm game. I didn't have my large base handy, so I apologise for the tiny base. Hags are a personal favourite of mine, as they are a great excuse for double crossing, magic and moral choices. That this one corrupts children and leads bands of ogres is just icing on the cake.

description.text: Wheel hub that mounts a standard 12mm hex RC wheel to a 5mm shaft on a NEMA17 stepper motor. After printing, I use a 6-32 tap to thread the hole for the wheel, and a hole for the set screw. I use inexpensive 6-32 machine screws from my local hardware store. I could try to engineer the threads into the part, but I've gotten much better results by just adding a small hole into the part where I want the threads and then thread them with a tap.

description.text: I liked the idea of the big lego Wreath, but wanted som thing small enough to be used as an ornament. Print out 6 branches and berries and snap them together.

Like most anime fans, I have a strong appreciation for Studio Ghibli. I first came up with this concept when brainstorming present ideas for some family members of mine, but it has taken me a while to get around to actually designing the models.

For those not familiar (or for those having trouble deciphering my poor artistic rendering of the characters), the dolls from largest to smallest are:
-Totoro (from My Neighbor Totoro, model remixed from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12146)
-Noface (from Spirited Away, model from scratch)
-Jiji the cat (from Kiki's Delivery Service, model inspired by https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:948676)
-Calcifer (from Howl's Moving Castle, model from scratch)

I tried to make them with enough tolerance to fit together while still having enough grab to stick together in a sturdy fashion. If you print them out and find they don't fit together, I am including my blender file to allow you to tweak the model easier.

I tried to keep the characters relatively close to proportional, which I was mostly successful with, but Jiji ended up being a fair bit larger than he would be compared to Noface and Totoro.

description.text:
This is a video card bracket for an older style of Velocity Micro Tower.
It is designed to go into the unthreaded holes in several of the unused HDD brackets, and hold up the extreme right edge of the video card.

Many Towers still do not have something built in for this and as video cards use a larger and larger heatsink with heavier materials, they tend to dip on the right corner and eventually cause a short that fries the mainboard.

They can also pull the PCIE slot right off the motherboard in some cases.

Please modify to your liking.

I have included the Sketchup files for tweaking and adjustments.

Make whatever use of it you can.

Enjoy!

This is a joint replica that allows you to glue it inside a 2x2 Lego plate (first you have to gouge out the ring from the bottom centre of the plate. It fits the ball joint like a glove. This will let you make custom heads for the MegaZord. You may need to sand or file the square base a wee bit for a better fit inside a Lego plate.

You can also print a lego plate, but I found the studs to be less than reliable and easy to pick off.

I did buy a load cell for measuring weight with my arduino but you need some platform to rest on it so the weight is applied at the right position. author: Cyrrus

description.text: Just a fun little tree topper, designed for my old Solidoodle 2 (0.3mm). Both sides have no real overhangs and make for an overall (mostly) hassle-free print.

The Final Product

The pictured product was 3d printed in two halves using a green ABS plastic and glued together. I scaled this up to 3.65 for the picture, but that was just because my printer bed is only 6"x6". Should print fine even larger. The eye whites were filled in with quick-dry white-out and a light green marker was used to clean up the edging around the eyelids. The colored pupils were also made with various markers.

We thought a horrifying monster from the Underdark would look good on our tree this year, so I made a rough (and printer-friendly) version in 3d. Originally planned on hollowing out the eye stalks for 11 colored lights, but was concerned about stability during the print.

I couldn't get the 623 bearing to fit into its slot in the idler without taking a knife to it, so I widened the hole by 0.4mm, making the width of the slot 4.8mm.

This is modified from the extruder on AxMod3DPrint's github as of 12/9/17, which can be found on the original extruder thingiverse page.

Edit 12/12/17: Added the STEP file because I dislike STLs, and there should be some format that people can actually work with.

author: Masterjuggler

description.text:
EDIT 12/13/2017: .STL files removed as I did not realize the model I used to Remix asked for "No Derivations" under its licensing. Sorry. If that author opens up his files for modification, then I can upload the .STL's again.

If you like the idea of Marbles or Ball Bearings for eyes, check out:
"Baby Dragon with Custom Eyes" https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2703746

Remix of: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18479
I borrowed the Marble idea from: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:348403

I loved the idea of using marbles or ball bearings for the eyes of creatures. I have uploaded several files for different diameters of eyes. If properly printed, the "eyes" should just snap in. You can test this by just printing an eye socket file and scaling it if needed. to get the marble back out of the test eye socket, I'd suggest drilling a small hole from the under side. If you use marbles, they should allow you to spin the marble to the preferred orientation of the inner swirl for what you like. Please note that not all marbles are perfectly round or even very close in diameter. The model I uploaded for marbles is for 0.625" +/-.005" dia eyes. I suggest measuring them with calipiers or micrometers before you print.

TreeFrog_375_eyes.stl is for 3/8" (0.375) diameter eyes.
TreeFrog_625_eyes.stl is for 5/8" (0.625) diameter eyes.

Printer: XYZ Da Vinci Mini
3D Modeler: AutoDesk Inventor w/ MeshEnabler Addon
3D Slicer: XYZware

Settings:
No Rafts
No Supports
10% Infill
Normal Shell
0.20mm Layer
Medium Speed

TreeFrog_375_eyes.stl
Filament: 3.3meters of 1.75mm PLA
Run Time: ~1.25 Hours

TreeFrog_625_eyes.stl
Filament: 10.7meters of 1.75mm PLA
Run Time: ~3.25 Hours

author: aclaire

description.text:
Re-mix of laser cut to print on 3D printer.
Print everything out and glue together!

Used the body from Blaze Carrito Hueco by Miniempoleon

Added tires, wheels and axles.

Took the tires from JP Monster Truck by chsdesign and modified them.

Super glue can be used to attach the axles and wheels.

Only the body will need support.

Truck is about 120mm long but can of course be scaled up or down if desired.

Please note: this is not a complete model, these are alternate parts for petergross3's masterpiece. you must download the original model in order to make use of these.
Original model can be found here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1391911
the following accessories are designed to fit these parts:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2702167 - Collapsible Ion Blaster
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2702145 - Matrix of Leadership
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2703648 - Energon Axe

Mostly I have separated sections of certain parts to be printed in different colours in order to minimize the amount of painting required to finish the model, for example: the eyes were seperated from the face, the vents from the helmet, all the light covers and so on. This was done in order to give me a slightly harder wearing end product, as it is intended for play.

Additionally, I have added the following features:

  • The neck was adjusted to allow a greater degree of movement
  • The cabin was slightly adjusted to allow cut-down lego window panes to be used for the windscreens.
  • The Matrix holder was adjusted to fit the Matrix of Leadership linked above.
  • The back, ribs, and backpack parts were adjusted to fit the collapsible ion cannon linked above.
  • An autobot logo was sourced from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1131435 and scaled to fit, and a locating tab was added to the left shoulder.
  • Some holes were added in the front wheel wells and the abdominal grille, for adding 2mm locating pins to lock the abdomen together in robot mode.
  • Folding driver and passenger seats were added in the forearms.
  • Locating slots were added to the hands to suit the ion cannon linked above. It is my understanding that the handle of this weapon is designed to fit an actual transformer, so I assume the slots should fit standard transformer weapons.
  • The spine and pelvis were altered for extra structural integrity.
  • The fuel tanks were redesigned, holes were added here and on the hips to add a locating pin to lock the legs in place in truck mode.
  • The knees have been modified extensively, giving them an extra axis of rotation, as well as adding a spring-loaded button to lock them in place while in robot mode.
  • Flaps have been added to the shins to cover the wheels while in robot mode, they also lock the feet in place in truck mode.
  • The ankles have been modified to give them an extra axis of movement

Plus probably a few others I can't remember.

The following parts are listed as black, but are intended to be painted chrome:
headlights, abs, fuel tanks and bumpers.

Clear parts are intended to be tinted using whatever means you have available, I used permanent markers and a paint-on clear coat. Colour as shown in the last three images.
for best results, chrome the surface they're attaching to before gluing.

The springs used in the knees are: 2.3mm OD 0.3mm Wire Dia 20mm Long Compression Spring

author: waltorg

title: Acme Screw Rack & Pinion or Worm Gear

description.text:
Attempt to create a Rack & Pinion / Worm Gear with an Acme Screw
The updated pinion is definitely an improvement.
wormgear438.stl is for 0.438 pitch diameter screws.

Inch dimensions. The pinions should be compatible with a 5 threads per inch, 1 inch pitch diameter acme screw.
Filenames containing "438" are for 0.438 pitch diameter, 10 threads per inch screws.

comments.text: Thanks for the reply! I am working with this item http://www.surplusshed.com/pages/item/m4598.html which seems at least close to an acme tooth profile. I will check the dimensions and see if I can get there by scaling. If not, is the Perl script or anything similar in any language, available for generating gears with other dimensions?
comments.author: jbeale

comments.text: The script is not really in a human-friendly format for customization.
comments.author: jbeale

comments.text: I really appreciate your making a custom gear, thank you! Cura reports that gear bounding volume is 1.4 x 1.4 x 0.4 mm in size, which is pretty small- maybe some units got changed, but I will try scaling it up. Looks like a factor of 25.4 (mm/inch) is about right.
comments.author: NateTG

comments.text:
No problem.
Yeah, it's in inch scale, so 25.4 is probably right.
If you print it, please let me know if the gear works.
comments.author: jbeale

comments.text:
I made a partial print of the gear and it does fit the worm screw I have (see the photos I put in Makes: link here).
Meanwhile, I have figured out a way to make an enveloping / throated pinion gear in OpenSCAD, by many repeated CSG operations removing segments of a rotating worm screw from a plain cylinder gear blank. Sort of "computational machining", the same way actual gears are carved out on a hobbing machine. Very memory / CPU intensive (eg. slow).
comments.author: NateTG

comments.text: Very memory / CPU intensive (eg. slow).
comments.author: jbeale

comments.text: Yes, I think the tooth spacing is good for the worm I have. Since you so generously offered... can I get a 60-tooth gear? I also need a 5 mm center bore but I guess I can do that that if the .stl imports into SCAD. And yes, you are right about SCAD taking forever to generate files with lots of CSG operations.
comments.author: NateTG

comments.text: The gear should be up.  I did some mesh simplification so it should work OK with OpenSCAD.
comments.author: jbeale

comments.text: The new 60T gear imports to SCAD ok and it looks good. I added a few holes and printed (see photo). My screw seems to mesh OK and can drive it, but it gives a little "hop" at each full turn of the screw. Watching it turn, I think the tips of the pointy spikes at the edge of the pinion gear are the problem, I will try sanding those down.
comments.author: NateTG

comments.text: Is it possible that the set screw on the screw is clipping the gear?
comments.author: jbeale

comments.text: That was the first problem, so I removed the setscrew. Even after a "haircut" with sanding paper to blunt the pointy ends of the gear, the worm does not ride quite smoothly. I suspect that the tooth spacing on my print is not perfect, and this type of enveloping gear demands accuracy for the right mesh action. I will do some more measurements but I may end up scaling the gear up by 1% or so.
comments.author: NateTG

comments.text: Hmm...  how bad is this 'hop'?
comments.author: jbeale

comments.text: Yes, I modified the gear to a thinner section, trimmed the pointy bits, scaled up 1%, and it seems to work better. You can see a video clip in my remixed thing here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:437087 but of course this was a very shaky setup, my thin brass tube shaft driving the worm may be warped, or who knows what. As you say, if I leave it running for a while (in a setup with straight shafts) the gear may wear in a bit.
comments.author: NateTG

comments.text: I can't really see the 'hop' in your video - that's the first driven assembly that I've seen it in.  With nothing to compare it to, it seems pretty smooth to me.
comments.author: jbeale

comments.text: Yes, the video shows my second attempt, upscaled in size 1% which seems better and I think reasonably smooth given my jury-rigged shaft setup. I didn't make a video of the first gear with more of a hop (but at first I was also using a warped plastic Lego Technic shaft, so that was part of it).
comments.author: NateTG

comments.text: What CAD tool did you use to create these?  I want to make an acme-thread worm gear to match the surplus worm screw I got, which has OD = 1/2 inch and DP = 32 (teeth per inch of diameter). I tried an involute gear of the right pitch, but the tooth shape not ideal for this screw. Is there an OpenSCAD version of this type of gear?
comments.author: jbeale

comments.text: They were generated using perl script.   I'm not aware of any parametric OpenSCAD file for worm gears like this, but I haven't really looked.  IIRC these are dimensioned for 1" screws with 0.2 pitch, so if your worm gear is indeed an acme gear, you might have decent results if you scale one of the pinions here by 1/2.
comments.author: jbeale

title: Tubshroom Sinkshroom support adaptor for sink

description.text:
Not sure if this is useful for others but I might as well share it. The Tubshroom is an amazing strainer and it fits in my bath tub drain hole perfectly. However, in my bathroom sink, it just falls in since there is no ledge inside the drain hole for the Sinkshroom to "sit" on. I created this adapter, to fill inside the drain hole to support the Sinkshroom. It fit's snug in my drain hole.

After printing, I brushed acetone all over the part to strengthen it. Included is the sketchup file so you can modify it to fit your own sink. You may need to cut down the length or extend it to fit your drain.

Watch my video review of the Tubshroom, if you don't know what this amazing strainer is. It replaces the drain plug in most tubs, sinks, showers and catches all the hair that would otherwise get caught and clog.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AkSMDo9GkS8

description.text: I needed a solution that allowed me to have access to my AppleTV remote whilst riding on my indoor trainer using Zwift. As I don't require the use of the Wahoo Elemnt during these training sessions, I decided to make use of the elemnt mount on my handlebars and create a remote holder that slotted into the mount. This is a 3dtopo model of the world's most famous cliff, ElCapitan. Yosemite Valley's El Capitan is a 3000 foot almost sheer vertical, sometimes overhanging, granite playground for the world's elite rock climbers. Although every crack, and many featureless blank sections, have been climbed the most popular route by far is the infamous "Nose" route. The first assent in 1958 took 47 days. The current record is less than 2 1/2 hours. I made the model from a LIDAR dataset available on http://opentopo.sdsc.edu/. The LIDAR point cloud was gridded to a 0.5m resolution. Because the data was collected from a plane some of the detail is missing on the shear vertical sections and the overhanging sections aren't rendered, so you had better not rely on this if you want to climb it. You can watch my tutorial video at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t4-ICkvyJv0 This thing was featured on the 3D Printing Today podcast available on iTunes, Stitcher radio or direct from the source at http://threedprintingtoday.libsyn.com/

What up, my knitters!

10mm x 125mm knitting needles with a hole at the rear for gluing in an appropriate length of 1.75mm PCTPE filament.

After printing, ream out the cross hole, then the rear hole with a #47 or 2mm bit. Chuck a needle up in a drill to sand (400 grit) it smooth. A dab of superglue will seat the PCTPE in the rear hole. Use PCTPE or Nylon since most other filaments become brittle as they absorb moisture from the air. The needles can be printed out of your favorite filament. Those pictured are Solutech PETG, which is buttery smooth after sanding to 400 grit.

Hat tip to LoboCNC for his circular needles. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2695231

title: Geared Heart, Beth's Hand Cranked Edition
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A good friend of my wife and I, Beth, is fighting aggressive cancer. Her husband Marc, after seeing the "Geared Heart, Hand Cranked Edition", asked my wife if I could make her an OSU (Oklahoma State University, her Alma Mater) colors version of the "Geared Heart, Hand Cranked Edition" that was easier for her to hold. This version is for her, printed in OSU orange and black. A static video of the prototype version is here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C4mJBISZZQ8&list=UUv_zm49u-RjnCJVwhUO-ecA. This is the "Base.stl" version. There is also a "Base Tall.stl" version that doubles the height of the base for those needing an extending grip area. The difference between this version and the previous is the base is now cylindrical, and the handle is now a wheel with an attached knob, making it easier to hold and turn for those with a weakened grip. We hope she gets well soon. Designed using Sketchup 8 and printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42.

Study "Assembly.skp"  
Determine whether you wish to print "Base.stl", or "Base Tall.stl" ("Base Tall.stl" has a larger grip surface for those who need it), then print whichever you chose.   Print remaining parts, all in the color of your choice.  
Assemble the emmett's heart parts to "Heart Center.stl" according to his instructions.  Use white lithium grease as he previously suggested to lubricate his gears.  
Assemble the remaining parts according to "Assembly.skp", following the break in procedure described in the previous version.  
If you have any assembly questions, feel free to post a comment.  
We wish you the best, Beth, Godspeed.

description.text:
A semi-automatic flywheel blaster designed for .50 full length foam darts. Uses DC brushed motors ranging from 130-180 can size and lengths, all flywheels under 36mm outer diameter will fit, and the center distance is 43mm crush. Top-loadable by default and that is the only option. Also not lefty friendly.

Extra options exist for a crappily designed optional foregrip and mount that replaces the central front component of the magwell, a 14mm tightbore cage option, and battery tray sizes ranging from 16mm of height to 24mm of height.

Assembly requires M3 screws (preferably countersunk for most sections) varying in length from 5mm to 20mm (Or 25 even depending on your choice of assembly). There is more than one way to fill in screw posts, and not all of them need to be used for respectable structural integrity. EDIT: A 2mm thick, 10 to 25mm long pin is also absolutely necessary for the pinion gear in the pusher rack. Also one extension spring 3cm in length for the pusher , as well as a spring the size and relative strength of a Retaliator catch spring for the mag release. Designed for use with full sized 15A to 21A switches.

Will fit on any printer with build volume about 140x140mm and over.

This is admittedly an extremely flawed design which is functionally inferior to a decent Stryfe in almost every way. It was mostly an exercise in learning for me to learn how to model and make something functional. Do not expect anything extraordinary or even worth your time if you take it upon yourself to assemble one. That said, feel free to do whatever you please with the files, no credit or attribution necessary.

author: boostfpv

title: IBM System/360 and /370 mainframe computer console pushbutton insert

description.text:
Here is my attempt at replicating the pushbutton insert for the IBM SYSTEM/360 and System/370 mainframe computers that were popular during the mid-1960s to late 1970s. These machines had operator consoles with numerous switches, lights and buttons ('blinkenlights') that all good computers had back then.

Instructions
Only the OpenSCAD parametric script is included rather than STL files so you can choose which pushbutton insert to produce, by uncommenting one (and one only at a time) button module between the START HERE and END HERE section. Comment out the Demo line first.

Hit F5 to colour render, and then F6 to finish render before hitting the Generate STL button.

Printing
PLA tests came out very well. ABS was very good too, but if using ABS check for dimensional accuracy (to width and height, given in the script) so they don't jam in the console panel, you may need to scale between 98% to 102% and run some test prints.
Print all inserts at 100% infill, especially the translucent one.
The ABS blue I have is too light compared to the real IBM blue. However the translucent grey was done in clear ABS and it isn't too bad (I have never been able to print a clear item with clear ABS btw).

Finishing
Print the special curve sanding block to sand the printing layers off the face of the insert.
Paint the text next using white oil-based enamel (eg. Humbrol, Tamiya etc.) for the opaque inserts, and black for the translucent insert. Do not worry about cleaning all the paint off the concave face to much as you are doing this as it will be removed in the next step.

Use wet and dry sandpaper, used wet from #500 grade to #1200 grade and then polish.
The sanding photo shows #500 sandpaper being used. It is completely possible to get a very nice smooth finish on the button face if time and care is taken.

Button insert text
This is a WORK IN PROGRESS thing, and I still have experimentation to do to get the font more accurate. The default font in the text library text_on_OpenSCAD (see see https://github.com/t-paul/text_on_OpenSCAD) is used to position the lines angularly into the curved face.

To do
I hope to replicate the indicator inserts which were backlit only (not a pushbutton) and usually had two parallel lines across the face to indicate this, eg. on tape units.

title: Mouse Cable Bungee Compact and Weighted

description.text:
This is a compact Mouse Cable Bungee weighted using United States quarters or whatever coin is similar to its size (in photos using 10NT Taiwan coins). It's small enough to be printed by mini 3D printers and takes up very little space on your desk. This print only uses about 15 grams of PLA. It'll fit approximately 8 United States quarters. This is remix of daLamorDesign's Mouse Cable Holder since that one was way too big.

2 NOTES:

TWO VERSIONS: There are two versions, one with a slightly elevated base (because many inexpensive 3d printers don't print pretty edges on sharp rounded corners), and one without just for aesthetics purposes. Then you print a cap that is placed AFTER you've filled the base with quarters.

PRO-TIP: It is recommended to use a fan to blow against the stick so you won't get drooping.

print_settings.Notes:: I have arranged the parts how I plan to print. A few will probably need supports. I added my own to the model of the main body because I wanted to try it to see how it does. If you want the body minus these send me a message and I will post the file.

description.text:
This should be ready to go. A few of the parts will need supports. I am going to see how they print using slicer supports. I also made a Left-Handed pick guard in case there are any lefties wanting this. Just mirror all of the body pieces and print the LH PICK GUARD.stl file to make a lefty version.

Please share any pics or thoughts on this if you print this. I put a lot of work into this and I hope others can make an awesome and unique guitar out of this.

UPDATED 12/23/17
I have printed all of these pieces. I have made a few changes and am uploaded new files with this. The new files with have V2 added to them. I am leaving the original files as well. The custom supports I added in the main body file didn't work as well as I had hoped. If I printed the main body again I would print it lying flat on it's back. The V2 body file has had the horn cut off to print separately and has holes added for the rear spring anchor bracket. I also modified the bridge mounting holes to accept "heat-set" thread inserts like these here: https://www.mcmaster.com/#threaded-inserts/=1atdkxn

I am also adding files to print the multi-color logo on the pick guard. I printed the one in the photos here by printing one layer of each color, leaving the previous print on the bed and printing right around it. The files are designed to print two layers like this, changing the filament 8 times. Layer height would be best at .2 for this to work correctly. It worked great for mine. Print the pick guard , logos, text, and borders upside down if you print these on a glass bed. I learned how to setup files for multi color printing from Joel (3D Printing Nerd). He has a great video of how to setup files to print in multi-color here: https://youtu.be/RE-ZgJ5vzXk

UPDATE: 12-30-17: Added an output jack bezel that I embossed a spider web on. Looks great on the guitar.

UPDATE: 1-7-18: Uploaded a custom knob I designed for this. I planned to have these professionally printed, so I uploaded in case anybody else wants to do the same.
ENJOY!!!!

UPDATE: 1-14-18: Watch for a version 2. This design assembled great. The parts all fit well. But there are a few things I need to fix. The bridge screw holes don't match the stock Fender tremolo for some reason. I checked the blueprint I found online and it turns out the holes are off almost 2mm. I am uploading a new main body model here shortly to fix this. Will delete this note when it is uploaded.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.200 mm

Infill:

Varies - see notes

Notes:

I am initially printing all of the body parts with a .200 resolution. I am using ZYLtech PLA as a test print for everything and I am heating the hot end to 215, bed to 70. Printing with three perimeter layers and three top and bottom layers. The infill will vary. Print speed is 50mm/sec. I may crank this up to 60.

Main body - I plan to use 50% infill using a honeycomb fill. Honeycomb is very strong. Should do a good job of creating a strong body.

The LH parts don't do anything but look pretty at first glance. But they do add support and make the overall structure more sturdy. 10%-20% infill should be more than enough on the upper and lower pieces since these two aren't doing much to stabilize the body. The two middle pieces I plan to print at 40% infill because they are placed right where the body tas the most force exerted on it by the strings and bridge springs.

The RH Lower piece isn't doing much either. 10%-20% should be fine for it.

I printed the pick guard at 20% infill. 2 top and 2 bottom layers. 2 perimeter layers.

I have arranged the parts how I plan to print. A few will probably need supports. I added my own to the model of the main body because I wanted to try it to see how it does. If you want the body minus these send me a message and I will post the file.

comments.text: Greetings! Can i fit your pickguard to my original stratocaster?
comments.author: Osmon

comments.text: If you have the 11 hole pick guard it should fit. There are different versions. If you have a different version you can always drill the holes to make it fit.
comments.author: Osmon

comments.text: The only thing I think I would add is a piece of all-thread or rod from under neck up the spring compartment for stiffness...
comments.author: FourDogs

comments.text: It may be needed. I am going to test it and see if the body flexes at all after installing the strings and the bridge. If needed, instead of the standard strat nut plate, I may machine a piece of aluminum that continues to the bridge spring pocket and tie it together that way. I personally don't see that adding much more support though. The bridge springs work opposite the strings. The strings are trying to pull the bridge up, while the springs are pulling it down. So the body shouldn't be pulled in either direction with much more force than it is being pulled in the opposite direction. Otherwise we would see 20 year old Strats folded in half. The pressure of these two forces is trying to pull the bridge towards the neck if anything. And the only thing keeping the bridge from being pulled forward is the screws in the front of the bridge. So I was thinking that would be the area where I might need to strengthen this. I may be wrong though. I will report back after I do some testing.
comments.author: FourDogs

title: Circular 2.5cm RFID flat mount for Gogoro 2 Scooter Fob

description.text:
This is a shaped adapter mount for 2.5cm RFID tags for people who live in buildings or have garages that use RFID for main door entry but don't want to carry two items and just have one.

The problem for the Gogoro wireless fob is that it's curved and makes it attaching or gluing flat objects very difficult. The fob isn't even consistently curved but rather an irregular oblong shape. So I've created a circular disk that fits around it, creating a flat plane. It is 2.5cm so it fits Gogoro 2 fobs perfectly. I used UV glue like 5 Minute Fix and Lazer Bond which worked perfectly. Now I don't need to carry extra items.

NOTE: This obviously does not include 2.5cm RFID tags, you can purchase them on many places online. Make sure you have a duplicator and that you are using 13.56mhz or 125khz to match.

Monoprice Maker Select Mini V2

description.text:
My family had a Blokus set missing a piece. Someone else thought I might be able to 3d print a replacement, which I can. I thought it was really cool that someone else thought of that though.

I found some pieces on thingiverse, but they were a different style, and measuring them, they were slightly smaller than what I have. I took some measurements from another piece and recreated a single square unit in openscad. Then I made a function to easily translate that a number of units in x and y, so you can build any piece you want.

If you're feeling adventurous, maybe you could print all 35 hexominoes.

Notes:

I printed at .2mm layer height since that was an even divisor of the thicknesses I needed.

I printed with a translucent green PETG to try to get close to the original.

I used no supports, though maybe I should have.

I made Eleaf iJust S holder and dust cap that look like a missile for fun.

I hope you enjoy it!

description.text:
I designed this bait release mechanism specifically for my ZMR 250 for fishing but it could fit other quadcopters if you can have the same mounting holes or don't mind drilling new holes in your bottom plate.
It has clearance holes to match 30.5mm flight controller mounts allowing it to fit flush with the bottom plate.
The release has been angled so that the weight being carried is as close to the center of the quadcopter as possible.

On a ZMR 250, the bait release is mounted to the frame using the same holes as the inner standoffs and slightly longer screws.

You will need:
1 x 9g Servo controller.
1 x paperclip or thin gauge wire to connect the servo to the release pin.

Don't have a 3d printer? You can purchase this model from my Etsy shop.
https://www.etsy.com/au/LockoCrafts/listing/578763795/3d-printed-quadcopter-bait-drop-release?utm_source=Copy&utm_medium=ListingManager&utm_campaign=Share&utm_term=so.lmsm&share_time=1512898305717

Designing takes time and resources, if you like and use my designs, please consider supporting me. Your support means a lot to any designer and encourages updates and new designs to be shared with the community.
https://www.paypal.me/pjlocko/3

Tevo Tarantula

I've been using 20 - 30% and just tried gradual infill steps: 5 and still had good strength.

Glass bed with gluestick for adhesion.
Depending on your 3d printer, the release pin should only only need a light sanding to run smoothly in the hole.

title: Rubber Band Catapult
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A simple catapult model, working on 1 or 2 rubber bands.
Should keep kids around 5 busy for a moment, throwing things all over the place.
Ammunition can be printed out of TPU (reducing the risk of broken glass), but dried peas should be OK as well.
Should be mostly harmless, annoying at the worst, and a good manual exercise for the kid (pretty hard to get it to fire in the right direction if you ask me)...

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The provided ammunition should be made out of TPU, and might require a brim to stay on the hotbed.
There should be 3 bars and 2 sides, also. The bars can be printed all at once, no problem.

The bars might need some filing to fit in the holes on the sides.
The cross on the arm is meant to be tied to the top bar with 1 or 2 rubber bands, there are several ways to do that, some of which will slide off less than others.
Also, a piece of tape across the bottom should help keeping the axle inside the holes. Otherwise it might jump out after every shot.

This is a little tool for drilling straight holes into the ceiling that also catches (most of) the dust that will fall while you are drilling. This reduces mess and also keeps the dust out of your eyes. The hole is sized for a 1/4" drill bit, and the slots on the side of the cup are crosshairs.  
Unfortunately in this design some of the dust will still come down the drill flutes and on to you. The second photo shows an example, if you look closely you will see the worst of the dust that did escape. But this small amount will wipe up easily with a cloth.  
If the tube were shorter, or the whole thing longer, then this might not be the case (ie the whole flute would be inside the cup). But you will have to make that version yourself.  
Designed in Autodesk Fusion 360 (f3d archive is included)

I printed this on a Replicator 2 at low quality settings (works just as well and faster). No support necessary. Print it in the orientation in the file, with the open part of the cup upwards, so that the surface that you press into the ceiling is flat.

description.text:
When I belay my climbing partner, I get a stiff neck from craning my neck to look upwards.
I saw other people with belay glasses, but was amazed how expensive the glasses were.

So I thought I was being clever and bought a pair of really cheap book reading glasses from Amazon. They arrived, but it turns out you can't flip the direction.

So instead I cut out the prisms and surrounds, and designed my own glasses using the arms.

The glasses I used are http://amzn.eu/3KMoJaU
'niceEshop(TM) HD Horizontal Loon Glasses Refraction Glasses Bed Prism Spectacles Glasses '
Cost £4 and took a few weeks to arrive.

The prisms are held pretty tightly here, but you'll need to use glue or similar to be sure.

Edit Feb 7th: Special glasses case created! https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2785809
Edit Feb 7th: So I've used these a couple of times now whilst belaying my leading partner. They do stop a crick in the neck, but they are quite odd to use- I find I talk much quieter than I would expect for the distance he is away from me!
Edit Feb 20th: After using these a couple of times, I'm 2/3 in favour of using them to prevent cricks in the neck.

This is an LED mirror frame.
You will need to buy a round mirror that fits in the mirror holder, LED strip to go into the slot in front of the mirror, a power supply to power the LED strip plus glues.
I have not printed this so, print at your own risk/time/filament.....I had planned to infill the base at 20%, then fill with sand prior to the top layer being printed, just to add some weight to the base.
Diameter of the mirror is 90mm, therefore you will need a mirror of 180mm across, and no more than 5mm thick.
LED strip, no more than 5mm wide, any colour. LED wires pass through the hole at the bottom of the round mirror frame.
Slicing it, look like there is more than 45 hours print time for all components. If you scale it down, the LED strip wont fit into the slot.

description.text:
This door latch and handle is made to fit a 4mm plexiglass sheet, just cut out a 22x15mm slot on the edge of the sheet and slide in the handle. Add a small amount of glue to hold it in place if necessary. Thread a piece of filament through the holes to hold the lever in place. Mount the strike with double-sided tape or use screws.

Everything prints without support. To make a nicer bridge, the upper hole (when printing the piece lays sideways) for the lever pin in the handle part does not go through the first bridging layer above the slot so it has to be opened with some fitting metal pin.

This is part of my take on the 'IKEA Lack printer enclosure' thing.

title: LED Schiene rail 200mm extendable

description.text:
There are thousands of LED strip holders, I know.
I wanted something that fits my printer, kitchen and workspace as well.
This thing is a system of parts that holds LED strip cut from spool to desired length.
The default length w.o. connectors is 200mm
Put the pieces together extend the lenght to much more.
I have mounted them to aluminium L-shaped brackets.
The pictures are showing the first (top) and the final version with two rails attached I have made.
The final clamps (for two rails side by side) come with one screwhole only.

Take two strips at least. The cheap LED strip I have bought does not make very bright lite.
"5M White 3528 SMD LED Strip Light Non-Waterproof 12V DC 300 LED"

The files:

  • the rails with or without finger type joint connector(s)
  • the clamps
    One is the endpiece holder (with 3mm hole) for mounting to surface
    The other clamp type is for holding the rails midways.

Feel free to simplify the setup again:
-take the simple clamps only or
-omit the clamps entirely - go with screws and big washers,
but have an eye on the parts on the strips, don't make any shorts then

You are free to glue the rails onto where the should sit as well.
I like the detachable mount version over the glued on.

description.text:
Clamp for vertical posts of Ikea's Stolmen shelf/storage system. The contraption with the hooks was basically motivated by "there ought to be a hook here". Designwise I tried to fit into the swedish aesthetics. When properly mounted, the gap between the halves almost vanishes.
Included are the hooked version and a basic empty clamp design for your perusal, both as STLs for meshmixing and as Fusion360 archive, should you go the engineering road.
The thickness and height do not correspond to the original clamps, but hey, we go plastic, the swedes went metal.
With the bolts tightened it gets loads of friction and grip. I did not manage to shift or turn it, so I did not leave tolerance for the soft padding usually included with the originals.

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Prints fine without support. A 0.2 layer height should do the job, but it's sunday and I had time to spare. Vary the infill based on your slicer, printer and experience.

Assembly

Just provide two M6 x 20 hex bolts and nuts. Self-locking if you like, in case you plan on a more permanent engagement. I purposedly did not use washers here. The dimensions are chosen so that the bolts are almost flush with the nut after tightening for a less workshop-y and more kitchen-y look

Do not over-tighten the nuts. Stop just before you hear the crackling sound of PLA giving in, the grip is surprisingly firm without going four digits on the torque wrench :) Or use Nylon.

description.text:
This is my Tronxy X3 Y-Bracket. Because I cut my y-belts exactly to size, I could not use other y-brackets already made, so I made my own. This bracket also gives you ~10mm extra distance going backwards, not that I use it at the moment. It still requires the metal angle bracket which I like because it's metal. This bracket is rock solid and does not require any extra length of belt to install. It also does not interfere with the bed.

Warning - Due to extra movement allowed backwards, you must make sure your wires are out of the way so as not to interfere with the y-stop switch. Also, if triggering off the y-roller wheel, the trigger switch must be upwards. Mine is downwards because I'm triggering off the y brace I have installed.

Goodluck!

title: Anet A8 Z motor mount for use with motor damper
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
this is a Z motor mount to keep the smooth rod off the motor when using dampers

for those who dont know, a damper gors between the frame and motor
it preforms 2 functions
1) it make the motors quieter
2) by seperating the motor from the frame, it lessens the chance of resonance. and resonance can result in severe vibrations that shake the printer vilonently.

if the rod is sitting on the damper then heres 2 issues with that.
a) the damer is bypassed, lessening the damers effictively.
b) the extra weight can slowly stretch the damer out.

in addition it includes a cap to keep the m3 nut from falling out during installation.

Printer:

Anet a8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

any

Infill:

20% minimum

Notes:

material choice.
PLA will print perfectly, no need to touchup
ABS will require touching up

i printed this with a 0.3 mm layer height using a .8mm nozzle (.35 is the maximum i can print but slowly, .4 and i cant heat the filament fast enough)

if you have good bridging then supoports are not needed.

this does not require any extra hardware.

basicly remove the support.
and disassemble the z motor asseblely and replace the acrylic z motor mount

you may also need to remove part of the cap inorder to accomidate the damper, as long as the smooth rod stays supported by the mount, it will be held in place.

i used a serrated steak knife to remove about 30% to accomidate my dampers.

Anet a8 Z dampers get bypassed with the smooth rods

if you have dampers installed in the z axis of your a8. do me a favor and look into the slot at the damper. if you have good lighting you may be able to see the smooth rod sittign on top of the motor.
this does 2 things.
a) bypasses the damper.
b) stretches out the damper.
both are not good. one lessens the life of the damper, the other makes the damper pointless.

this solves both issues

heres the original mount heres my mod

description.text:
A simple Curtain binder to hold the curtain together and make it look organised.

Curtains are binder easily by wrapping the binder around, then passing the head through the hole and leaving it as is.

Please do share photos if you print this item, especially in any material other than TPU.

There are three variations 150, 200 and 250 mm based on how broad the curtains are, and how tight you want them binded.

If unsure, just use a thread around the curtain's circumference however tight you want , and measure it using ruler, and then print it!

If your bed size isn't big enough, you can print two of smaller size, and then club them with one other, kinda like using two small zip-ties to make a bigger tie.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

No

Notes:

Recommend printing using flexible material with 3-4 bottom and top layers, and no infil.

Print settings like speed and extrusion would be based on your material.

I recommend 3 perimeters, but 2 would print just fine.

Can be printed in ABS or PLA, but that would require the Z height to be scaled down to 0.4mm instead of 1mm, so that only 2 layers are printed at 0.2 mm layer height, both solid.

description.text:
In fact, I was sure that sooner or later my apple tv remote would crash, and I decided to protect it with a bumper. I found one in thingiverse really simple and practical and I printed it, but I found a problem and is that I was not happy with how it felt to click so I decided to design my own bumper.
I started from this design https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1168972 reducing its bevel, this way the touch of the click was good, but the bumper came off easily, so I decide to print a rigid part to fit in the flexible, and this is the result.
The internal part is designed to be printed in flexible filament and the exterior is designed for rigid (I used PLA). Rubbers bands are printed in flex aswell.

PRINTING INSTRUCTIONS

You need to print 5 parts:

  • RUBBER:Very easy and fast to print, you must print twice in flexible filament.

  • INTERIOR BUMPER: you must print in flex or it wont work. It's very important to print with th "UP" facing down. The indication is only to adjust the remote control.

  • EXTERIOR BUMPER:It is splitted into two parts. I have separated them by 1mm to simplify their printing. I suggest to print with supports and remove carefully once done.

description.text:
Optimized for Semiflex/Cheetah. Ninjaflex will probaly work, too.
Some softer types of pla may work, but the hinge can break eventually.

Customizer doesent seem to like the imported stl, so you may need to download the .scad file and use Openscad locally to customize (its free!).

Customizable types: Wallet Case, Flip Case, Bumper
Customizable text: You can add your own name or signature in customizer, by default its "OnePlus"

Default settings:
Wallet Case with 3 credit card pockets, one extra pocket and an integrated stand.

We all suffer from bad bed adhision from time to time, why not use it to our advantage?
When adding a small air gap between layers they still adhere during printing but can be seperated to form pockets :-)
I used Simplify3D, not tested with other slicers.

If you have problems separating the layers add a small piece of tape at the air gaps during printing. Usually its enough to have a 3mm wide opening to insert a screw driver and succesively open the pocket. I used a piece of kapton tape for the stand only, you can see it on the picture (yellow tape). If you use too much tape the layers may separate during printing which can cause deformation or a failed print.

You should use a flexible material for flip and wallet case styles, as the hinge can break after some time with harder materials.
Optimized for Semiflex/Cheetah, but sucessfully used Taulman PCTPE (which is a combination of Nylon and TPE=Ninjaflex), too.

Fairydust rocket

I printed the original in pieces and glued them together, but was not happy with the glued connections. It broke.

To give it some extra strength, I remixed it in Solidworks and created a central channel to fit in an M4 threaded rod I had laying around. The rod will fit down the entire length and will stick out in the pommel. I glued it in with epoxy in the tip and used the piece sticking out to temporarily fit a nut during the glueing process. After glueing you can cut off the end of the rod. Just be careful of the heat. If you cut it off with a dremel, the threaded rod can get really hot and melt your print!

I included the solidworks sldprt files for easier remixing.

author: Kenseiden

title: Air blast switch
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Air blast switch utilizing a standard 20x6x9 mm microswitch.
You need to add is a rubber membrane 30mm diameter 0,9mm thick (e.g. cut from a bycicle inner tube). Glue that into the ring and glue the little pressure plate onto the membrane to avoid wear.
Glue a hose into the top part of the housing (5 - 6 mm; enlarge hole if necessary)
Use 3mm screws and nuts to fasten housing.

Dependent on the qty of air you blast into the switch you might want to drill a small (very small) hole into the top of the housing to avoid overpressure.
As it is not airtight, it can be used as a surge switch only.

With that umbrella carrier you can drive your bicycle without any restrictions and you are protected from the rain from the feets up to the shoulder.

Meanwhile, I use it more than a year with different umbrellas and I still like it. On a rainy day I mount the umbrella in a few seconds at the bike, drive to my work and then take the umbrella to get dryly to work.

You have to print LenkstangenHalter23 and LenkstangenHalterUnten23 two times if you Mount the carrier on the handlebar with up to 23 mm Diameter. If your handlebar is thicker, print Lenkstangenhalter32 and Lenkstangenhalter32 which can be used up to a Diameter of 32 mm.
By the way you Need a M6 Maschine screw with two Standard nuts and one M6 self-locking nut for inside of the SchirmhalterschieneOben.
Additionally, you Need of course four Long M4 screws with nuts to Mount the carrier on the handlebar.

Assembe the umbrella carrier

Use Rändelkopf for the end of the Maschine Scew and put the nuts inside the hexagonal wholes of the Schirmhalter. Turn the screw through the whole with the two nuts. Afterwards turn the screw into the SchirmhalterschieneOben with the self-locking Screen inside.
Afterwards, you can Mount the carrier on the handlebar.
